title: How to Remove Polyurethane From Your Hands

steps.title: Apply mineral spirits for a quick option.
steps.content: Apply mineral spirits for a quick option. Only use mineral spirits if you have access to a well-ventilated room without the risk of flames, like a bathroom with an open window. Using an old hand towel or rag, apply enough mineral spirits to soften the oil-based polyurethane from your hands. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use vegetable oil for a gentle solution.
steps.content: Use vegetable oil for a gentle solution. You may also use cooking oil, like vegetable oil. Simply dab a rag or paper towel with oil and apply to the polyurethane on your skin. [3] X Research source For extra scrubbing power, combine 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) of olive oil (or another oil for your choice) and 1/3 cup (96 g) of salt and stir. Scoop a generous amount and rub the mixture into your skin for approximately 2 to 3 minutes to remove the stain.

steps.title: Try paint thinner.
steps.content: Try paint thinner. Pour enough paint thinner to coat your hands onto a rag or paper towel. Wipe down each part of your hand before rinsing with soap and hot water. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Use rubbing alcohol or denatured alcohol.
steps.content: Use rubbing alcohol or denatured alcohol. Pour a decent amount of alcohol onto a rag or paper towel and rub the stained areas until the polyurethane fades. Apply more alcohol if needed. This method will be harsher on your skin, leaving it dry, so moisturize well when you're done. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Apply acetone nail polish remover.
steps.content: Apply acetone nail polish remover. If you or someone in your house has nail polish remover with acetone, grab it. Soak a rag, paper towel, or cotton balls in the remover and wipe any polyurethane away. [6] X Research source If the polyurethane hasn’t dried onto your skin yet, this is a fast removal method. If it has dried onto your skin, you may need to rub it hard or allow it to soak for a few minutes.

steps.title: Use soap and warm water to clean your hands.
steps.content: Use soap and warm water to clean your hands. Allow your choice of solvent (mineral spirits, oil, paint thinner) to sit on your skin for a minute. Then, wash your hands with warm water and soap to remove any solvents from your hands. Be sure to rinse thoroughly. [7] X Research source If your hands still feel sticky, apply more solvent and repeat the process until your hands are clean.

steps.title: Finish up with moisturizing lotion.
steps.content: Finish up with moisturizing lotion. Apply a generous layer of moisturizing lotion to soothe skin irritation and restore moisture to your hands.

steps.title: Apply dish soap and water.
steps.content: Apply dish soap and water. Use a dish soap like Dawn with surfactants, a chemical that can penetrate and lift grease, oil, and dirt from many surfaces. [8] X Research source Refer to the back of your dish soap for the ingredients and look for one of the following: Anionic surfactants include Sodium Laurel Sulfate (SLS), Sodium Laureth Sulfate (SLES), and Linear Alkyl Benzene Sulphonic Acid (LABSA). These are the most common surfactants in dishwashing liquids. Nonionic Surfactants are milder and ideal for people with sensitive skin. These include Fatty Alcohol Polyoxyethylene Ether (AEO-9) and Cocamide DEA. Amphoteric Surfactants include Cocamidopropyl Betaine and Cocamidopropylamine Oxide. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Use a pumice stone to scrape off the polyurethane.
steps.content: Use a pumice stone to scrape off the polyurethane. Loosen and remove polyurethane from your hands by gently rubbing it with your nails. If it's really stuck, use a pumice stone or a sponge with a rough surface to scrape the polyurethane from your hands. [10] X Research source If polyethylene has dried on your skin, you may need to soak your hands in warm water and soap for a few minutes.

steps.title: Rinse your hands under warm water.
steps.content: Rinse your hands under warm water. Rinse your hands under warm water for at least 30 seconds. If there’s still a stain, repeat these steps until your hands are clean. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Apply moisturizing lotion.
steps.content: Apply moisturizing lotion. After you’ve dried off your hands, apply a generous layer of moisturizing lotion to prevent skin irritation and keep your hands soft. Hand cream can also be used as a preventative measure to protect your skin from polyurethane.
